[Repost. Pardon the =3D20 and =3D2Es]

<quote>
> This is all definitely wor=
th knowing, but my immediate guess is that
> the JUnitDoclet user is (re)ge=
nerating far too many tests at once,
> irrespective of whether those tests =
say fail() or not

If you mean, that in a non-TDD environment, there are ma=
ny
empty test methods in the beginning, that is true. (The next
version of =
JUnitDoclet will at least count them and print that
number as warning.) But=
 as a coach I actually have seen a
remarkable thing:

  Because it is so ea=
sy to write a test _then_ (once there is
  a place for it) they get written=
 naturally. Developers know
  the importance of tests, the just need help t=
o get started.
</quote>

It is easy to write a test then, but it's not nece=
ssarily the proper test
to write=3D2E Test-After leads to a testing methods=
, rather than testing
behavior=3D2E One of the points of TDD is to identify=
 what behavior is requi=3D
red
up front, then implement just enough of it=
=3D2E There is already overhead to=3D

writing unnecessary code; there is m=
uch more overhead in testing
unnecessary code=3D2E Generating test stubs ab=
dicates the programmer of his
responsibility to ask himself the question, "=
Do I need to test this method=3D
?
Do I even need this method at all?" That=
's one reason why I distrust the
Test-After process=3D2E

Still, that's eas=
y for me to say, because I don't have millions of lines o=3D
f
untested (an=
d untestable) legacy code standing between me and the delivery=3D

date=3D2=
E I have respect for the people who effectively deal with that probl=3D
em=
=3D2E

<quote>
> It is important for us to remember our TDD bias=3D2E :)

B=
TW: Did you ever consider to generate a test from an empty=3D20
but compila=
ble application method? Still the test can be=3D20
_implemented_ before the=
 tested method does something=3D2E=3D20
</quote>

Yes, I have considered it=
; but I prefer to write the test first, because i=3D
n
so doing, I may find=
 out that the method I wanted to write really needs to=3D

be something els=
e entirely=3D2E

I have had this discussion with quite a few of my (then) I=
BM colleagues,
one of whom asserts that writing the test immediately after =
writing the
code is the same as writing the test before the code=3D2E The b=
ottom line is=3D

that as long as the individual thinks about the test firs=
t, that's what is=3D

important=3D2E To do otherwise creates more problems =
to refactor away from=3D2E=3D


Take care=3D2E

--JBR
